title: _Advertisement_
sourceDesc: The first two Books of Hume’s [Treatise of Human Nature] were published together in 1739. The third Book, which included an Appendix making some changes to Book 1, was published in 1740. There was only one edition published in Hume’s lifetime, an this edition is therefore our copytext.
author: David Hume

blocks.content: _MY design in the present work is sufficiently explain'd in the _introduction_. The reader must only observe, that all the subjects I have there plann'd out to myself, are not treated of in these two volumes. The subjects of the _understanding_ and _passions_ make a compleat chain of reasoning by themselves; and I was willing to take advantage of this natural division, in order to try the taste of the public. If I have the good fortune to meet with success, I shall proceed to the examination of _morals_, _politics_, and _criticism_; which will compleat this _Treatise of human nature_. The approbation of the public I consider as the greatest reward of my labours; but am determin'd to regard its judgment, whatever it be, as my best instruction._
